Award.AwardTitle: Positron and Positronium Collisions with Simple Atoms
Award.AbstractNarration:
Two projects are to be performed in the area of theoretical atomic physics. The first project involves using a well established method to study low-energy scattering of an exotic atom, positronium (Ps), from the conventional atoms hydrogen (H) and lithium (Li). This project is of interest since Ps-H scattering is a fundamental four-body Coulomb process and Ps-Li scattering is an effective four-body Coulomb process. A graduate student will work on the project for his Ph. D. dissertation. The project involves an international collaboration with Dr. Peter Van Reeth, who is in London, UK. The second project concerns the search of vortices for positron-hydrogen ionization. It is timely due to the recent explanation of the previously unexplained minimum in results for electron-impact ionization of helium and the development of positron reaction microscopes. The project is in collaboration with Dr. Joseph Macek and Dr. Serge Ovchinnikov who are at the University of Tennessee, Knoxville.

Positronium scattering has applications in astrophysics, biophysics and condensed matter and vortices are important in many fields of physics such as fluid dynamics, astrophysics, condensed matter and nonlinear dynamics. The plan is to present results through publication, at national conferences and at an international conference. To provide the graduate student a broad exposure to inquiry-based and other pedagogical methods, the graduate student will assist Teach North Texas (TNT), a program at UNT that prepares future secondary mathematics and science teachers. Novel program features developed by TNT will be disseminated at conferences concerning teacher preparation for science and mathematics.

Angular Momentum is an important physical quantity in classical and quantum mechanics that is conserved. Conservation of physical quantities such as energy and angular momentum is of extreme importance in physics.

We have studied theoretically a particular scattering process of fast electron impact ionization of an inner-shell of a carbon atom.

We used the Coulomb-Born method which is a quantum mechanical method that allows for transfer of angular momentum.

The Coulomb-Born approximation is important since it gives the correct high energy limit for ionization for fixed scattering angles.

We obtained a zero in a the ionization transition matrix element which is a quantity that gives information on the scattering process, and this zero is relates to the physical process of angular momentum transfer.

A vortex in the velocity field of the ejected electron is associated with the zero in the transition matrix element. For the first time for electron impact ionization we have obtained a segment of a vortex line for a particular set of kinematics. Vortices have previously been obtained for electron-impact ionization of helium, as well as ionization by proton, antiproton and positron projectiles. In addition to vortices being of importance and fundamental in atomic  physics, vortices are of interest in other areas of physics such as in astrophysics, fluid dynamics and condensed matter.

A paper on the vortex work for inner-shell ionization of carbon by electron impact has been accepted for publication and it has been presented at national meetings.

The work was done in collaboration with Dr. J. H. Macek (University of Tennessee).

 

A second project has been the investigation of a fundamental four-body Coulomb process, namely, low-energy elastic positronium-hydrogen scattering. This work is the Ph. D. dissertation project of a physics graduate student, Mr. Denton Woods. We have an international collaboration on this work with Dr. P. Van Reeth (London, UK). Positronium is an exotic atom that consists of a positron and electron. It is similar to hydrogen, but has a positron rather than a proton. The low-energy region is of particular interest since for this energy range the particle correlations are important. A fundamental four-body Coulomb process is of interest because a system involving three or more charged particles has not been solved exactly either quantum mechanically  or classically.  We have obtained accurate results for low-energy elastic positronium-hydrogen scattering, and in some cases, benchmark results, using the well established Kohn variational method and variants of the method. The methods are fully quantum mechanical.

Measurements of positronium scattering from a number of atoms (not hydrogen) and molecules have been made by the University College London positron group. In addition to positronium scattering being of interest in atomic physics, it is also of interest in the fields of astrophysics, biophysics and condensed matter.
